subject: Re: [junit] Using real data or test data?

messageBody:
I'll throw in our $0.02 worth. One of our projects runs daily against
the stock markets, so the data changes daily. In addition to new data
from the daily trading, stock symbols change, and change back again
weekly. So using the live data would result in constant breakage of test
cases.
However, I agree that real data has exactly the kind of real-world
anomalies that one needs to test against, and I know of no way to fake
those kinds of data.

So, we use several test databases, which are snapshots of the
real-world data from the live sites. This way we have static datasets to
test against, but we have all the kinds of data anomalies that our
software encounters in the real runs. It requires a bit of storage, but
once we have a set of test cases to run against, we never have to touch
them again. As the project has grown, and we have discovered new tests
(to handle anomalies that we had not seen previously) we add a new test
suite that references a new snapshot of the real-world environment,
while the older test cases continue to refer to their own snapshots.

This seems to work for us, in a fairly dynamic real world domain,

Jim

haefeleuser wrote:


>We test various ERP programs, like purchasing demand calculation
>(complex business logic).
>
>I think it is a better approach to use test data which cover the
>various use cases or boundaries instead of real data. With "test data"
>I mean data which I create in my test program and which I persist in
>the database. After the test finished, I delete the test data (with an
>EntityGarbageCollector).
>
>But our new project leader thinks we should use only real data ("one
>dataset for all tests"). I don't think that this would work. We need
>both strategies I think, even if one solution seems to be redundant.
>
>To only use real test data has big disadvantages in my opinion:
>- if data changes (real data does), then tests break
>- you need much more real data than test data to cover all the
>boundaries and use cases
>- if you add real data or remove real data from the dataset, tests
>might break
>
>What do you think about it?
>
>
>
>
